ai.summary: A challenging 21.1 km circular hike in the Monnow valley, United Kingdom. The route weaves through farmland, woodland and riverbank sections, with several ascents and descents that suit experienced walkers with solid navigation and good fitness.
ai.terrain_summary: Varied terrain: grassy field paths, forest tracks, riverbank trails, and passes through gates and stiles. Expect rolling ascents and descents, with occasional rocky or muddy sections and potential boggy ground after rain.
ai.safety_notes: Plan for a long day and check weather forecasts before you go. Navigation can be tricky in open valley terrain, so bring a map and compass (or a reliable GPS) and know how to use them. Wear sturdy waterproof boots and dress in layers; conditions can change rapidly in the UK. Be prepared for mud, rain, and exposure on higher sections. Watch for livestock in fields and close gates behind you. Carry enough water and snacks, a basic first aid kit, a whistle, and a light source if your hike may extend into dusk. Inform someone of your planned route and expected return time.
recommended_gear: Sturdy, waterproof hiking boots with good ankle support
Weatherproof jacket and insulating layer; hat and gloves for cold weather
Map and compass (or reliable navigation device) with route clearly planned
Fully charged phone with offline maps and emergency contacts
Water bottle or hydration system (2–3 liters) and extra snacks
Headlamp or small flashlight with spare batteries
Trekking poles (optional but helpful on long ascents)
Extra layers and a compact rain cover for your pack
ai.best_seasons: Spring to autumn (roughly March to October) are best for this hike; winter hikes can be muddy and exposed, requiring extra preparation and caution.
